and you need to define `Foo.contextTypes` everywhere as well
<@U044JU5CA>: I use a flux implementation that passes a flux object through the context and I'm actually really liking it
do you need to use contextTypes with that?
yeah, for anything with context you do, that's the only annoying part
and in ES6 classes it seems you can only write them after you've defined your class
create a text snippet
yeah context is still not final in react.js. i dont like context but who cares what i like :wink:
it'd be fine if I didn't have to write contextTypes like that
messes up the cleanness of writing `export default class Foo extends React.Component {`
I've used context for a year now :wink: and i prefer react.createclass still because of a couple of these problems...
this.context.hipster
:stuck_out_tongue:
yeah I guess maybe I should stick to createClass for now
hehe my friend actually found it before any documentation came out, hes crazy
jumping the gun a bit
but you can write it old style using ```export default const Foo = React.Class({ contextTypes: {something: React...}});```

Guys this question would have been asked many times. Please bare with me. Here is the scenario, built an isomorphic react application with nodejs. Simple tasks were easily rendered by server, and I didn't add any browserified files for static markup. But when the application involved any event handlers like on click, browserified the same component and added to the script tag of server rendered page. This works fine. Here is the problem : so there is a dynamic mongodb query and as per the query, the page is rendered. The page also has some on click events, in this case how can I pass the json from dynamic mongodb query to browserified client components.
<https://twitter.com/ahmetcetin/status/708240043366866945>
Hey <!channel> checkout our latest project in React
<https://www.seaofthieves.com>
<@U0C1G59MX>: awesome!
Cheers
Anything happening here?
is it possible to access <http://asp.net|asp.net> mvc "ViewModel" from reactjs script?

You can make an ajax call to a controller that returns the ViewModel you are looking for and if you return as JSON from the controller you can access it. You can't access the native C# ViewModel on the server.
so for example if the "ViewModel" (JSON) is a list of Items, can I manipulate the data returned? i.e. add new item (row)?

You may want to check out a thread specific to <http://ASP.Net/AJAX|ASP.Net/AJAX>. You can do this in reactjs, it's just JavaScript, but it really has nothing to do with reactjs.
Once you get the JSON back from your controller, you can deserialize the JSON to an object that you can manipulate in JavaScript. You can add, remove items and post the updated object to your <http://ASP.net|ASP.net> controller so you can work with the updates on the server.

`this.props.children`
I mean if I have an action like update. I think contextTypes is what I am after
when does proptype validation occur in the lifecycle of a component?

At render time, React calls the function checkPropTypes for each component to be rendered, passing in the componentName, props, propTypes and location. checkPropTypes iterates over the supplied propTypes, calling each function in turn with the relevant props, propName, componentName and location. If the returned value is of type Error or if the function throws an exception, the error's message is written out to the console via React's warning function (using console.warn).

question for 1mil ... I've started one quite big project.. using redux redux-thunk and react... after I made my first action, reducer for homepage.. I realized that I am not sure where I should put the validations like async response when something is wrong with API but also field validation... I've checked a lot of articles... some of them are telling put it into action reators and reducers... but Dan Abramov is allways telling "keep reducer simple stupid" ... so I am a bit confused... Does any1 has the experience with it?? Thanks :slightly_smiling_face:

<@U0DKUDX7Y> What about putting API async call and response manipulation on actions? For instance there you can subscribe to a certain behaviour and then do something with the response:

```
// Let's say you want to get a dog from an api that exposes dogs
export const fetchDog = (id) => (dispatch) => {
  dogsApi.getDogById(id).subscribe(
    (data) => {
      console.log('this is my dog', data);
      dispatch(doSomethingWithDog(data)); //this is another action where you now manipulate the response
    },
    (error) => {
      console.log('parsing failed', error);
    },
    () => {}
  );
};
```
Then the appropiate reducer should know what to do with the state after you have done the request

<@U1Y4XEX7D> yeah I am doing something like that .. in my action.js file

export function loadRestaurants() {
  return function (dispatch) {
    return fetch('API_URL_HERE').then(
      restaurants => dispatch(loadRestaurantsSuccess(restaurants)),
      errors => dispatch(loadRestaurantsError(errors))
    );
  };
}

and in my reducer

...
case types.LOAD_RESTAURANTS_ERROR:
      console.log('reducer: ', action);
      return action.errors;
...

what is weird and I don't know why..that the error is pushed into store.restaurants but not into store.errors =/
<@U0DKUDX7Y> in this project any validation is made, maybe will help You <https://github.com/rajaraodv/react-redux-blog>
Here is description that author made <https://medium.com/@rajaraodv/a-guide-for-building-a-react-redux-crud-app-7fe0b8943d0f>

<@U3RL094UU> it seems you re using jQuery inside it. Its not a good practice to mix jQuery and ReactJS. Both have a diferent way of manipulating the DOM, and can result in inconsistencies and unexpected behaviour. What you should be doing there instead is dispatching an action that will be handled by a reducer and then affect the store. There you should modify some condition or state that makes the button disappear or sth like that.
<@U3RL094UU>: you should bind action in constructor and not in render method

hey Guys, when it comes to routes, do you know what is the difference between declaring child routes and just doing it directly? So I can have a route /a and declare a child route that I call b, so I will have a/b or I can just have a and then declare a second route (not as child) and give it a path of a/b
is there a considerable difference?
<@U3VGTE66T> , when declaring child routes, the child components will be wrapped by it parent

what are the pros and cons? I noticed that the child routes components are children of the parent component. The thing is, not everytime I am at a parent route I go further to a child, meaning that in this situation the children components (from the child routes) are not used...can this be a downside of it?
eg
it means that some logic/authorization may be put in `Profile` and the children got benefit from it

hi mates, I have a problem
I have a component Element. I have a loop where I create multiple Elements
each Element has an state calls owner
and when the component its created I call and action in order to update the owner
but the states of all Elements update with the same value
like they were sharing their states
How could I fix that? :confused:
what’s your code look like <@U48T17H6G>
my component:
the reducer:
the action:
And how I render the component:
so, when I call requestOwner action from each component, the state is shared to all of them and this shouldn't happen

emesislol: You should do the request outside of your GalleryElement. Let’s say on gallery container. And then, store each information you want to fetch within an array with a common state key, for example `{ ‘gallery-owners’: [] }`. Then when you’re mapping each GalleryElement you should pass the corresponding index of that array of information you want to pass.
thanks <@U43PCD4KC> ! I will try to do that :smile:
Let me know if you find a better approach :slightly_smiling_face:

Anybody have any thoughts on how to test external URL’s in Jest?
I’m just looking to test if an external API endpoint’s status is 200
You shouldn't need to test external urls in jest, as they are a third party. You should be testing how your components / service handles response by using mock objects
Here's an example
<https://hackernoon.com/api-testing-with-jest-d1ab74005c0a>

<@U6ALCDYRL> I'll sometimes see people create a separate test directory for tests that exercise third party libraries / APIs, just so they can understand how it works and know if/when it's behavior changes. You could try using something like Axios to make the calls. Not sure what type of endpoint you're referring to though.

Thanks for the replies guys, I wouldn’t typically use Jest to test external URL’s. But, I think on this occasion it’s justified.
I was experimenting by building an image placeholder component and wanted part of my test suite to ping the external URL’s of each service to see if they are still available (e.g <http://placeholder.com|placeholder.com>, <http://unsplash.it|unsplash.it>).
It does make it more an integration test and not a unit test though
Interesting, any recommendations / best practices on integration tests in React?

It's not specific to react. Just keep the different categories of tests in separate folder structures. Be able to run your unit tests quickly, but make sure you run the integration tests on your CI builds.
Devs don't need to run integration tests on their machine if there are a lot and they take a long time to run.

Hi guys, could someone confirm whether it is possible to combine react native and a webapp?
with one single code I mean

I think there are some solutions, but as far as I'm aware, Facebook's intentions with React and React native weren't to "learn once, deploy anywhere", but more like "learn once, write anywhere". I was interested in this topic as well but at this point I'm afraid (correct me if I'm wrong) there's no easy way to have the same code base for web and mobile apps.
<@U66KHUXSR>
you might want to abstract some components and keep them in a common repository perhaps, but I've never done anything in React Native so I'm not sure how that would work.
<@U66KHUXSR> You can take a look at <https://github.com/necolas/react-native-web>
but as whole I agree with <@U5NFL7N1M>
ok thanks, I had a look a this react-native thing, which is why I asked for confirmation

<@U67U5JMEY> Material-UI is quite nice. I didn’t have any performance issues when I used it a few months back. It can be a little confusing with the syntax and all, but that’s just in the beginning. Then you’ll get used to it.
Just search your code for React.PropType
Is now a separate package and needs to be imported : 'prop-types'
If it's not in your code then it's more than likely a component you have imported

<@U6FDSB3UJ> If something isn’t working currently, it’s probably totally unrelated to the warnings you’re seeing. Generally speaking, errors are the things that actually stop your code from working. Warnings are just letting you know about stuff that isn’t suggested best practice (but still works), or is deprecated (will probably stop working with the next version.)
<@U6D0T96CA> I think he means clicking on bundle.js doesn't show him the cause of the warning, which it won't as it will go to the warning function
Ah, I see. I thought he had something else that wasn’t working, and wanted to track down warnings because he thought they were the cause. Good luck either way!
<@U6FDSB3UJ> there’s not much you can do about these warnings. The package is deprecated. Your code should still function properly though. You’ll just have this annoying warning on your console.
